      • boundCheck

        private static void boundCheck()
        %BOUNDCHECK [ ON | OFF ]

        Controls generation of array bound checking, if possible on the given implementation. The initial setting is ON.

      • copy

        private static void copy()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        %COPY file-name

        Will cause the compiler to include the indicated file at this place in the source input stream, as if the text was actually written in the module containing %COPY. COPY (or INSERT) may occur in the included file: The included lines are always counted, i.e. they will be numbered sequentially, starting from the number of the line of the COPY-directive.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • definition

        private static void definition()
        %DEFINITION

        This directive is relevant only in a separately compiled procedure or class. The compiler will regard this compilation as a prototype definition only, i.e. the module is checked for syntactic and semantic correctness, and the appropriate attribute element is produced, but no code generation is performed.

      • endFile

        private static void endFile()
        %EOF

        When the compiler recognizes this directive it reacts as if the end of the source file was encountered, i.e. it terminates reading and, if this module was inserted (see INSERT/COPY), source scanning will continue after the INSERT (COPY) directive in the enclosing file.

      • insert

        private static void insert()
                    throws java.io.IOException
        %INSERT file-name

        Will cause the compiler to include the indicated file at this place in the source input stream. INSERT may occur in the included file. In contrast to COPY, the included lines are not counted (they will all be numbered with the line number of the line containing the outermost INSERT). Furthermore, if the source is being listed, listing is turned off during the inclusion and turned on again when reading continues after this directive.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • list

        private static void list(java.lang.String t)
        %LIST [ ON | OFF ]

        %NOSOURCE - same effect as %LIST OFF

        %SOURCE - same effect as %LIST ON

        Use of this directive controls whether or not the succeeding lines of the source text shall be listed. %LIST OFF will suspend listing, while %LIST ON will resume listing. If listing was not requested when the compilation was started (see compiler options) these directives have no effect. The initial setting is ON.

      • noDummy

        private static void noDummy()
        %NODUMMY [ ON | OFF ]

        Supress the generation of dummy inspection-blocks. In order to have effect the directive must occur before the first connection statement affected.

      • noneCheck

        private static void noneCheck()
        %NONECHECK [ ON | OFF ]

        Controls the generation of checks for whether a reference attribute is none when it is used as a pointer. The initial setting is ON.

      • page

        private static void page()
        %PAGE

        Will cause the compiler to change to a new page in the listing file. If the page heading (as defined by %TITLE, see below) is non-empty, it will be printed on top of the new page.

      • quaCheck

        private static void quaCheck()
        %QUACHECK [ ON | OFF ]

        Controls the generation of qualification checks, both explicit and implicit. The initial setting is ON.

      • reuse

        private static void reuse()
        %REUSE

        Normally, termination of a procedure or block will leave the corresponding object as a (non-referenced) block in the heap. This area cannot be used until the heap is compacted (by the 'garbage collector'). When REUSE is ON during compilation, such objects are reclaimed when released if they are at the moment on top of the heap. The initial setting is OFF.

      • select

        private static void select()
                    throws java.io.IOException
        %SELECT select-character { select-character }

        Set selectors for conditional compilation.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • setOption

        private static void setOption()
        %SETOPT option-character { option-character }

        For each character in the option-character string, the corresponding selector is set. All selectors not in the string are reset.

        Selectors are used to decide which conditional source lines to be scanned. 

         Example:
     %+MD-F  while(x>45)
        The statement "while(x>45)" is compiled only when selectors 'M' and 'D' are set and 'F' is reset.

      • setSwitch

        private static void setSwitch()
        %SETSWITCH number1 number2

        Will set compiler switch 'number1' to the value 'number2'. The facility is intended for compiler maitenance, and is not explained further.

      • sourceLength

        private static void sourceLength()
        %SLENGTH last-column

        The argument must be a positive integer. The directive will cause the compiler to scan only columns 1 through 'last-column' of the source lines. The directive may be useful in case the source text has e.g. sequence numbers in the last positions of each source line, or when compiling a set of source files of varying widths. Initially the compiler will scan the complete source line.

      • sport

        private static void sport()
        %SPORT [ ON | OFF ]

        Enables/disables special features of any S-port SIMULA compiler, such as inclusion of the S-port library

      • setStandardClass

        private static void setStandardClass()
        %STANDARDCLASS

        Used to compile 'standard classes' to indicate simplified block structure. In addition all 'procedures' will be treated as Java Methods.

        The initial value is false. See DeclarationScope.java

      • setTitle

        private static void setTitle()
                      throws java.io.IOException
        %TITLE title-string
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • setUseQualifiedNames

        private static void setUseQualifiedNames()
        %QUALIFIEDNAMES

        Used by Java-Coding to generate fully qualified class/procedure names.

        Consider a class A with local class B, then the 'qualified name' B is 'A$B' where is added to make the name 'A$B.java' unique within the file directory.

        The initial value is false. See DeclarationScope.java

      • setKeepJava

        private static void setKeepJava()
                         throws java.io.IOException
        %KEEP_JAVA directory-string
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
